temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 我们如何才能开发出变革性的思想工具？ in the user temberature at 2022-05-24T05:50:43
item.description:
in reference to:

Adobe 与许多其他软件公司的共同点是，他们的大部分专利都是防御性的：他们把一些想法申请专利，以便专利恶霸无法通过类似的相互起诉他们。这样与理想情况大相径庭。创新型公司很容易受到专利恶霸的攻击，这些恶霸有庞大的专利库，其中专利的权利要求广泛而模糊，也没有多少细节，不费吹灰之力。但是，一旦创新型公司投入更多来实现一个非常不错的新创意，其他公司总能复制该创新的核心，对其进行合适改变，以合理地规避任何专利侵权。专利制度没有保护应该保护的东西。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 我们如何才能开发出变革性的思想工具？ in the user temberature at 2022-05-24T05:56:52
item.description:
in reference to:

虽然硬件可以被复制，但它往往比复制软件要昂贵得多。而且不仅如此，这类公司的优势往往在于分销、营销，以及与为该平台生产产品的供应商的关系。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 加粗几个字母之后，英语阅读速度原地起飞，真的这么神奇吗？ in the user temberature at 2022-06-02T07:15:27
item.description:
in reference to:

从这个角度来讲，仿生阅读也未必适用于所有文章。沈阳师范大学曾做过一项文本标注对中文阅读眼动的研究。研究显示，虽然添加高亮会指引和帮助参与者们更好地记忆重点内容、忽略干扰内容，但如果含有错误标识或标识过多，那与无标识的阅读效率几乎是一样的。同时，如果阅读的文本是比较简单的内容，那标示也未必可以提高正确率。

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 将想法送入你的轨道（Orbit） in the user temberature at 2022-06-05T05:05:35
item.description:
in reference to:

记忆：重复回忆问题；时间间隔随着回答成功/失败而呈指数级扩大/缩小 过程的流畅性：重复完成简短练习，有许多变体；时间间隔随着成功/失败而呈指数级扩大/缩小 卡片写作：重复问题、模糊的想法、主干想法，从中积累思考，时间跨度为几个月；将卡片标记为「有成果」或「无成果」，以扩大/缩小时间间隔 习惯养成：重复简短的反思卡片，可能根据顺序改变，应用于你的日常经验；间隔默认扩大，但可以放缓 阅读队列：一系列 PDF，标签页，书本，总在变换：如果一段时间内忽略某些内容，它就会暂离一周，之后是一个月；比如说「我现在读够什么了」，这东西就会几天之内再次呈现；说某个东西「不是现在读」，那就几个月，之后是几个月之后再呈现…… 电子邮件收件箱、任务队列、个人通信等

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.description:
in reference to:

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 中医这件事 in the user temberature at 2022-06-25T14:17:45
item.description:
in reference to:

所以后来索性把医生的眼睛也蒙起来——不告诉医疗人员哪组是安慰剂组哪组是实验组，所有的结果由第三方机构去统计和评判，这就是双盲对照实验。这种测试最大限度地排除了病人的安慰剂效应和医生的主观偏好，成为了判断药物客观疗效最有力的证据，现代医学的“金标准”。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:25:54
item.description:
in reference to:

I focused almost entirely on optimizing when I should review the material. My partner made to realize that any spaced repetition algorithm is only half of the story. The other half is how you engage with the material.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:30:38
item.description:
in reference to:

With the benefit of hindsight, one glaring problem is that, what you do to increase the levels of processing (increasing comprehension and making connections) is beyond the scope of any spaced repetition systems; they’re not conducive to (deep) thinking and making connections.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:44:26
item.description:
in reference to:

From now on, my focus on “how to learn” would be shifted from “when should I review this” to “what should I do when I indeed review this?” It’ll be about thinking frameworks and mental models; it’s about “what and how to think” instead of “when to think.”

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:33:32
item.description:
in reference to:

Give it time and it will become second nature.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:34:35
item.description:
in reference to:

You are still using your head. At some point most of the things that are vim related won't be processed by your brain but by your muscle memory.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:35:29
item.description:
in reference to:

The downside (下行) is that when that happens, you will be entirely vim brainwashed.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:35:35
item.description:
in reference to:

Over time you will figure out your preferred motions and work flow. You will develop muscle memory for most of it and it will be intuitive (直观) and instinctive (本能) .

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:44:45
item.description:
in reference to:

Learning to use vim really is like learning a language. You're still "translating" in your head instead of just "speaking" naturally. Just keep practicing and it will become second nature with time.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:01:10
item.description:
in reference to:

But you can define your own types as well.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:02:55
item.description:
in reference to:

Alternatively, you can combine the --only-matching (or -o for short) with the --replace flag to achieve the same result:

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:05:43
item.description:
in reference to:

ripgrep will never modify your files. The --replace flag only controls ripgrep's output. (And there is no flag to let you do a replacement in a file.)

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:20:33
item.description:
in reference to:

ripgrep passes the file path as the first and only argument to the command and also sends the contents of the file to stdin.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:20:42
item.description:
in reference to:

With preprocess in the same directory as 1995-watson.pdf

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated ripgrep/GUIDE.md at master · BurntSushi/ripgrep in the user temberature at 2022-08-25T12:22:54
item.description:
in reference to:

If you wind up needing to search a lot of PDFs, then ripgrep's parallelism can make the speed difference even greater.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 金融消费者如何购买 in the user temberature at 2022-08-30T15:08:35
item.description:
in reference to:

、合同条款复杂、坑多，金融机构抱怨消费者预期高、拒绝承担风险、不理智。究其原因在于，消费者自身和金融机构对于消费者的金融行为都没有认知和把握。 本书全面梳理了消费者金融行为这个重要但“冷门”的主题，话题涉及常见的金融行为，包括投资、保险、借款、储蓄、资金管理、缴税和规避欺诈，综合了各个主题最前沿的研究，并且以案例结合观点展开阐述。 本书讨论了人们金融行为的决定因素和条件，如个体差异和个性、对风险得失的理解、自信、信任、风险偏好、时间偏好、决策制定和自我调控等等，分析了针对不同的金融消费行为，这些因素是如何地影响着

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 年度征文 | 我是如何艰难地克服「效率成瘾」的？ - 少数派 in the user temberature at 2022-09-01T03:30:41
item.description:
in reference to:

对于 DEVONthink 来说，我觉得它最重要的就是 Search 搜索功能。比如说我通过 Alfred 的 DEVONthink 插件快速输入「重器轻用」，然后我就可以搜到在 DEVONthink 里面所有关于「重器轻用」的信息。而这个搜索速度是极快的，并且在右侧边栏，你可以看到搜索结果有一个展现的区域，让你快速知道哪些地方有相关文字的一个出处。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/devonthink - Is DEVONthink worth it? in the user temberature at 2022-09-01T04:02:11
item.description:
in reference to:

I suppose it depends what you want to use it for. I use it for research mainly. It is excellent for document storage and analysts and it has been a game changer for me. Coupled with its ability with RSS feeds and Devon agent, I have to say it is superb. I suspect I’m only scratching the surface of its capability. It is a pretty steep learning curve but it’s capabilities are massive.Have a look at the videos on www.screencastsonline.com there is a free membership for 7 days which should give you some idea of what it is capable of. They were a great intro for me.

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How many words do you need to speak a language? in the user temberature at 2022-09-01T15:14:21
item.description:
in reference to:

If you learn only 800 of the most frequently-used lemmas in English, you'll be able to understand 75% of the language as it is spoken in normal life.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How many words do you need to speak a language? in the user temberature at 2022-09-01T15:15:11
item.description:
in reference to:

Eight hundred lemmas will help you speak a language in a day-to-day setting, but to understand dialogue in film or TV you'll need to know the 3,000 most common lemmas.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How long does it take to master a language like a native speaker? in the user temberature at 2022-09-02T03:10:21
item.description:
in reference to:

I find that memorizing a number of ‘filler’ words or sentences can greatly increase your ability to come off as native, as well as knowing some expressions and sayings. Instead of expressing agreement with a simple ‘yes’ you could try responding with “you know what? I Agree!” or “I think I see what you mean”. It’s agreement either way but it sounds a lot more ‘native’.
